update.description:
Changes in sdformat to support proper debian guidelines. From the top of my head:

 * Split package into: libsdformat1 (ABI will be keep between minors) and libsdformat-dev  
 * Proper copyright file (DEP-5)
 * New libsdformat1-dbg (using DebWithRelInfo to build)
 * All ubuntu distros share the same debian metadata (except changelog)
 * Runtime dependencies are handled via shlibs
 * Support for parallel building

This will serve as early work to back to gazebo transition. My plan is to start building nightly using this scheme and change gazebo dependencies to look for ```libsdformat1 | sdformat```.

Thanks to @thomas_moulard who inspired this work and I'm sure will provide good feedback on this.
update.title: Adapt sdformat to debian packaging policy

I think that we have all ready.

content.raw:
Sorry I don't see any easy fix on this one.
However I would set the CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR explicitly in the dh_auto_configure step to avoid moving around libraries during the install step.
The real advantage is that you will get the right path into the process and avoid moving aroud things and breaking things if at some point you embed your LIBDIR path into your binary.
content.html: Sorry I don't see any easy fix on this one. However I would set the CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR explicitly in the dh_auto_configure step to avoid moving around libraries during the install step. The real advantage is that you will get the right path into the process and avoid moving aroud things and breaking things if at some point you embed your LIBDIR path into your binary.

content.raw:
The wiki page is already containing what you want:

```
debian/%.install: debian/%.install.in
       sed 's/@DEB_HOST_MULTIARCH@/$(DEB_HOST_MULTIARCH)/g' $< > $@
```

https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch/Implementation#Dynamic_debian.2F.2A_files
content.html:
The wiki page is already containing what you want:

debian/%.install: debian/%.install.in
       sed 's/@DEB_HOST_MULTIARCH@/$(DEB_HOST_MULTIARCH)/g' $< > $@

https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch/Implementation#Dynamic_debian.2F.2A_files

content.raw:
Understood. We can not use dh-exec in precise, version 0.3 is needed, version 0.2 is in precise. So the only way seems to be generating a ```.install``` files from ```install.in``` files containing $DEB_HOST_MULTIARCH@ to be replaced. 

Do you know a rules files doing this kind of substitution?
content.html:
Understood. We can not use dh-exec in precise, version 0.3 is needed, version 0.2 is in precise. So the only way seems to be generating a .install files from install.in files containing $DEB_HOST_MULTIARCH@ to be replaced.

Do you know a rules files doing this kind of substitution?

content.raw:
Sorry for the double post.

I double checked.
Starting from Ubuntu 11.04, Multiarch is supported:
https://wiki.ubuntu.com/MultiarchSpec

```
Ubuntu 11.04 introduces support for installing packages from multiple architectures on a single system. This makes a wider array of 32-bit applications available to users of 64-bit Ubuntu.
```
content.html:
Sorry for the double post.

I double checked. Starting from Ubuntu 11.04, Multiarch is supported: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/MultiarchSpec

Ubuntu 11.04 introduces support for installing packages from multiple architectures on a single system. This makes a wider array of 32-bit applications available to users of 64-bit Ubuntu.

pull_request.title: Adapt sdformat to debian packaging policy

pullrequest.title: Adapt sdformat to debian packaging policy

content.raw:
Not on my computer:

```
$ cat /etc/issue         
Ubuntu 12.04.3 LTS \n \l

$ cat -n multiarch /usr/share/cmake-2.8/Modules/GNUInstallDirs.cmake
[snip] 
    71  if(NOT DEFINED CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR)
    72    set(_LIBDIR_DEFAULT "lib")
    73    # Override this default 'lib' with 'lib64' iff:
    74    #  - we are on Linux system but NOT cross-compiling
    75    #  - we are NOT on debian
    76    #  - we are on a 64 bits system
    77    # reason is: amd64 ABI: http://www.x86-64.org/documentation/abi.pdf
    78    # Note that the future of multi-arch handling may be even
    79    # more complicated than that: http://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch
    80    if(CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME MATCHES "Linux"
    81        AND NOT CMAKE_CROSSCOMPILING
    82        AND NOT EXISTS "/etc/debian_version")
    83      if(NOT DEFINED CMAKE_SIZEOF_VOID_P)
    84        message(AUTHOR_WARNING
    85          "Unable to determine default CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR directory because no target architectur
e is known. "
    86          "Please enable at least one language before including GNUInstallDirs.")
    87      else()
    88        if("${CMAKE_SIZEOF_VOID_P}" EQUAL "8")
    89          set(_LIBDIR_DEFAULT "lib64")
    90        endif()
    91      endif()
    92    endif()
    93    set(CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR "${_LIBDIR_DEFAULT}" CACHE PATH "object code libraries (${_LIBDIR_DEFA
ULT})")
    94  endif()
[snip]
```

AFAIK you are only supporting multiarch enabled distributions so I am not too sure what was the issue here?

If you need to support non-multiarch compatible distrobs, see:

1. https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch/Implementation#dh.281.29_and_autotools
2. https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch/Implementation#Dynamic_debian.2F.2A_files


Shortly: another way is to just generate the *install files using a simple Makefile rule and a small tool called dh-exec.

It is very easy to do! :)
content.html:
Not on my computer:

$ cat /etc/issue         
Ubuntu 12.04.3 LTS \n \l

$ cat -n multiarch /usr/share/cmake-2.8/Modules/GNUInstallDirs.cmake
[snip] 
    71  if(NOT DEFINED CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR)
    72    set(_LIBDIR_DEFAULT "lib")
    73    # Override this default 'lib' with 'lib64' iff:
    74    #  - we are on Linux system but NOT cross-compiling
    75    #  - we are NOT on debian
    76    #  - we are on a 64 bits system
    77    # reason is: amd64 ABI: http://www.x86-64.org/documentation/abi.pdf
    78    # Note that the future of multi-arch handling may be even
    79    # more complicated than that: http://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch
    80    if(CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME MATCHES "Linux"
    81        AND NOT CMAKE_CROSSCOMPILING
    82        AND NOT EXISTS "/etc/debian_version")
    83      if(NOT DEFINED CMAKE_SIZEOF_VOID_P)
    84        message(AUTHOR_WARNING
    85          "Unable to determine default CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR directory because no target architectur
e is known. "
    86          "Please enable at least one language before including GNUInstallDirs.")
    87      else()
    88        if("${CMAKE_SIZEOF_VOID_P}" EQUAL "8")
    89          set(_LIBDIR_DEFAULT "lib64")
    90        endif()
    91      endif()
    92    endif()
    93    set(CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR "${_LIBDIR_DEFAULT}" CACHE PATH "object code libraries (${_LIBDIR_DEFA
ULT})")
    94  endif()
[snip]

AFAIK you are only supporting multiarch enabled distributions so I am not too sure what was the issue here?

If you need to support non-multiarch compatible distrobs, see:

  1. https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch/Implementation#dh.281.29_and_autotools
  2. https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch/Implementation#Dynamic_debian.2F.2A_files

Shortly: another way is to just generate the *install files using a simple Makefile rule and a small tool called dh-exec.

It is very easy to do! :)

pullrequest.title: Adapt sdformat to debian packaging policy

content.raw:
This should probably be `/usr/lib/<arch>/cmake/sdformat/`.

See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10765885/how-to-install-your-custom-cmake-find-module

CMake will be available to find the module here too out of the box so the move should be transparent to the user.
content.html:
This should probably be /usr/lib/<arch>/cmake/sdformat/.

See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10765885/how-to-install-your-custom-cmake-find-module

CMake will be available to find the module here too out of the box so the move should be transparent to the user.

content.raw:
You are not escaping the dot in the extension properly.
Also, you may want to relax a bit the archive extension (uscan behaves correctly if the same release is available in different formats):

`http://gazebosim.org/assets/distributions/sdformat-(\d\.\d\.\d)\.(?:zip|tgz|tbz|txz|(?:tar\.(?:gz|bz2|xz)))`

See https://wiki.debian.org/debian/watch/
content.html:
You are not escaping the dot in the extension properly. Also, you may want to relax a bit the archive extension (uscan behaves correctly if the same release is available in different formats):

http://gazebosim.org/assets/distributions/sdformat-(\d\.\d\.\d)\.(?:zip|tgz|tbz|txz|(?:tar\.(?:gz|bz2|xz)))

See https://wiki.debian.org/debian/watch/

content.raw:
Is there any reason to disable tests all the time?
You may pass nocheck to `DEB_BUILD_OPTIONS` to skip this step in your buildfarm while keeping a sane behavior by default.
content.html: Is there any reason to disable tests all the time? You may pass nocheck to DEB_BUILD_OPTIONS to skip this step in your buildfarm while keeping a sane behavior by default.

content.raw:
Please remove these two lines.
You are forcing the buildfarm to run in verbose mode which is considered a bad practice.
It does not prevent you from calling debuild (or any other build script you use) with these right options set.
